618.01Â Â Â DOGS AND OTHER ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE; NUISANCE, DANGEROUS AND
VICIOUS DOGS; HEARINGS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â âDangerous dog.â
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A dog that, without provocation, and subject to division B. of
this definition, has done any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Caused injury, other than killing or serious injury, to any
person;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Killed another dog;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Been the subject of a third or subsequent violation of Ohio
R.C. 955.22(C) or any substantially equivalent municipal ordinance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â âDangerous dogâ does not include a police dog that has caused
injury, other than killing or serious injury, to any person or has killed
another dog while the police dog is being used to assist one or more law
enforcement officers in the performance of their official duties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â âMenacing fashion.â A dog that would cause any person being chased
or approached to reasonably believe that the dog will cause physical injury to
that person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â âNuisance dog.â
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Subject to division B. of this definitions, ânuisance dogâ means
a dog that without provocation and while off the premises of its owner, keeper,
or harborer has chased or approached a person in either a menacing fashion or
an apparent attitude of attack or has attempted to bite or otherwise endanger
any person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â âNuisance dogâ does not include a police dog that, while being
used to assist one or more law enforcement officers in the performance of
official duties, has chased or approached a person in either a menacing fashion
or an apparent attitude of attack or has attempted to bite or otherwise
endanger any person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â âPolice dog.â A dog that has been trained and may be used to assist
one or more law enforcement officers in the performance of their official
duties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â âSerious injury.â Any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any physical harm that carries a substantial risk of death;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any physical harm that involves a permanent incapacity, whether
partial or total, or a temporary, substantial incapacity;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any physical harm that involves a permanent disfigurement or a
temporary, serious disfigurement;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any physical harm that involves acute pain of a duration that
results in substantial suffering or any degree of prolonged or intractable
pain.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â âVicious dog.â
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A dog that, without provocation and subject to division B. of
this definition, has killed or caused serious injury to any person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â âVicious dogâ does not include either of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A police dog that has killed or caused serious injury to any
person while the police dog is being used to assist one or more law enforcement
officers in the performance of their official duties;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A dog that has killed or caused serious injury to any person
while a person was committing or attempting to commit a trespass or other
criminal offense on the property of the owner, keeper, or harborer of the dog.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â âWithout provocation.â A dog acts âwithout provocationâ when it was
not teased, tormented, or abused by a person, or it was not coming to the aid
or the defense of a person who was not engaged in illegal or criminal activity
and who was not using the dog as a means of carrying out such activity.
(ORC 955.11(A))
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â No person, who is the owner or keeper of horses, mules, cattle, bison,
sheep, goats, swine, llamas, alpacas, or poultry, shall permit them to run at
large in the public road, highway, street, lane, or alley, or upon unenclosed
land, or cause the animals to be herded, kept, or detained for the purpose of
grazing on premises other than those owned or lawfully occupied by the owner or
keeper of the animals.
(ORC 951.02)
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â No owner, keeper, or harborer of any female dog shall permit it to go
beyond the premises of the owner, keeper, or harborer at any time the dog is in
heat unless the dog is properly in leash.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Except when a dog is lawfully engaged in hunting and accompanied by
the owner, keeper, harborer, or handler of the dog, no owner, keeper, or
harborer of any dog shall fail at any time to do either of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Keep the dog physically confined or restrained upon the premises of
the owner, keeper, or harborer by a leash, tether, adequate fence, supervision,
or secure enclosure to prevent escape;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Keep the dog under the reasonable control of some person.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â Except when a dangerous dog is lawfully engaged in hunting or training
for the purpose of hunting and is accompanied by the owner, keeper, harborer,
or handler of the dog, no owner, keeper or harborer of a dangerous dog shall
fail to do either of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â While the dog is on the premises of the owner, keeper or harborer,
securely confine it at all times in a locked pen that has a top.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â While the dog is off the premises of the owner, keeper, or
harborer, keep that dog on a chain-link leash or tether that is not more than
six feet in length and additionally do at least one of the following: keep the
dog in a locked pen that has a top, locked fenced yard, or other locked
enclosure that has a top; have the leash or tether controlled by a person who
is of suitable age and discretion or securely attach, tie, or affix the leash
or tether to the ground or a stationary object or fixture so that the dog is
adequately restrained and station a person in close enough proximity to that
dog so as to prevent it from causing injury to any person; or muzzle that dog.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â No person who has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to three or more
violations of division (d) of this section involving the same dog and no owner,
keeper, or harborer of a dangerous dog shall fail to do the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Obtain liability insurance with an insurer authorized to write
liability insurance in this state providing coverage in each occurrence because
of damage or bodily injury to or death of a person caused by the dangerous dog
if so ordered by a court and provide proof of that liability insurance upon
request to any law enforcement officer, county dog warden, or public health
official charged with enforcing this section;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Obtain a dangerous dog registration certificate from the County
Auditor pursuant to division (j) of this section, affix a tag that identifies
the dog as a dangerous dog to the dogâs collar, and ensure that the dog wears
the collar and tag at all times;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Notify the local dog warden immediately if any of the following
occurs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The dog is loose or unconfined.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The dog bites a person, unless the dog is on the property of the
owner of the dog, and the person who is bitten is unlawfully trespassing or
committing a criminal act within the boundaries of that property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The dog attacks another animal while the dog is off the property
of the owner of the dog.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â If the dog is sold, given to another person, or dies, notify the
County Auditor within ten days of the sale, transfer, or death.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â No person shall do any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Debark or surgically silence a dog that the person knows or has
reason to believe is a dangerous dog;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Possess a dangerous dog if the person knows or has reason to
believe that the dog has been debarked or surgically silenced;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Falsely attest on a waiver form provided by the veterinarian under
division (h) of this section that the personâs dog is not a dangerous dog or
otherwise provide false information on that written waiver form.
Â Â Â (h)Â Â Â Before a veterinarian debarks or surgically silences a dog, the
veterinarian may give the owner of the dog a written waiver form that attests
that the dog is not a dangerous dog. The written waiver form shall include all
of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The veterinarian's license number and current business address;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The number of the license of the dog if the dog is licensed;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A reasonable description of the age, coloring, and gender of the
dog as well as any notable markings on the dog;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The signature of the owner of the dog attesting that the owner's
dog is not a dangerous dog;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â A statement that division (F) of Ohio R.C. 955.22 prohibits any
person from doing any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Debarking or surgically silencing a dog that the person knows or
has reason to believe is a dangerous dog;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Possessing a dangerous dog if the person knows or has reason to
believe that the dog has been debarked or surgically silenced;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Falsely attesting on a waiver form provided by the veterinarian
under Ohio R.C. 955.22(G) that the personâs dog is not a dangerous dog or
otherwise provide false information on that written waiver form.
Â Â Â (i)Â Â Â It is an affirmative defense to a charge of a violation of division
(g) of this section that the veterinarian who is charged with the violation
obtained, prior to debarking or surgically silencing the dog, a written waiver
form that complies with division (h) of this section and that attests that the
dog is not a dangerous dog.
Â Â Â (j)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The County Auditor shall issue a dangerous dog registration

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A fee of fifty dollars ($50);
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The personâs address, phone number, and other appropriate means
for the local dog warden or County Auditor to contact the person;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â With respect to the person and the dog for which the registration
is sought, all of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Either satisfactory evidence of the dogâs current rabies

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Either satisfactory evidence of the fact that the dog has been

or spaying of the dog is medically contraindicated;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Satisfactory evidence of the fact that the person has posted

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Satisfactory evidence of the fact that the dog has been
permanently identified by means of a microchip and the dogâs microchip number.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Upon the issuance of a dangerous dog registration certificate to

renew the certificate annually for the same fee and in the same manner as the

of this section and, upon the expiration of the certificate issued in the
original county, shall renew the certificate in the new county.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â If the owner of a dangerous dog for whom a registration

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the owner of a dangerous dog for whom a registration

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Provide written notice of the new address to the County

Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The owner of a dangerous dog shall present the dangerous dog

(ORC 955.22)
Â Â Â (k)Â Â Â Hearing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The municipal court or county court that has territorial
jurisdiction over the residence of the owner, keeper, or harborer of a dog
shall conduct any hearing concerning the designation of the dog as a nuisance
dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If a person who is authorized to enforce this chapter has
reasonable cause to believe that a dog in the personâs jurisdiction is a
nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog, the person shall notify the owner,
keeper, or harborer of that dog, by certified mail or in person, of both of the
following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â That the person has designated the dog a nuisance dog, dangerous
dog, or vicious dog, as applicable;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â That the owner, keeper, or harborer of the dog may request a
hearing regarding the designation in accordance with this division (k). The
notice shall include instructions for filing a request for a hearing in the
county in which the dogâs owner, keeper, or harborer resides.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â If the owner, keeper, or harborer of the dog disagrees with the
designation of the dog as a nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog, as
applicable, the owner, keeper, or harborer, not later than ten days after
receiving notification of the designation, may request a hearing regarding the
determination. The request for a hearing shall be in writing and shall be filed
with the municipal court or county court that has territorial jurisdiction over
the residence of the dogâs owner, keeper, or harborer. At the hearing, the
person who designated the dog as a nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog
has the burden of proving, by clear and convincing evidence, that the dog is a
nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog. The owner, keeper, or harborer of
the dog or the person who designated the dog as a nuisance dog, dangerous dog,
or vicious dog may appeal the courtâs final determination as in any other case
filed in that court.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â A court, upon motion of an owner, keeper, or harborer or an
attorney representing the owner, keeper, or harborer, may order that the dog
designated as a nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog be held in the
possession of the owner, keeper, or harborer until the court makes a final
determination under this section or during the pendency of an appeal, as
applicable. Until the court makes a final determination and during the pendency
of any appeal, the dog shall be confined or restrained in accordance with the
provisions of division (e) that apply to dangerous dogs regardless of whether
the dog has been designated as a vicious dog or a nuisance dog rather than a
dangerous dog. The owner, keeper, or harborer of the dog shall not be required
to comply with any other requirements established in this Code or the Ohio
Revised Code that concern a nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog, as
applicable, until the court makes a final determination and during the pendency
of any appeal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â If a dog is finally determined under this division (k), or on
appeal as described in this division (k), to be a vicious dog, Ohio R.C 955.11
(D) and divisions (e) to (j) of this section apply with respect to the dog and
the owner, keeper, or harborer of the dog as if the dog were a dangerous dog,
and Section 618.21 applies with respect to the dog as if it were a dangerous
dog, and the court shall issue an order that specifies that those provisions
apply with respect to the dog and the owner, keeper, or harborer in that
manner. As part of the order, the court shall require the owner, keeper, or
harborer to obtain the liability insurance required under division (f)(1) in an
amount described in division (l)(5)B. of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â As used in this division (k), ânuisance dogâ, âdangerous dogâ, and
âvicious dogâ have the same meanings as in Ohio R.C. 955.11.
(ORC 955.222)
Â Â Â (l)Â Â Â Penalty.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Whoever recklessly violates division (b) of this section is guilty
of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(ORC 951.99)
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Whoever violates division (c) of this section or commits a
violation of division (d) of this section that involves a dog that is not a
nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog shall be fined not less than
twenty-five dollars ($25) or more than one hundred dollars ($100) on a first
offense, and on each subsequent offense shall be fined not less than seventy-
five dollars ($75) or more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250) and may be
imprisoned for not more than 30 days.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In addition to the penalties prescribed in division (l)(2)A. of
this section, if the offender is guilty of a violation of division (c) of this
section or a violation of division (d) of this section that involves a dog that
is not a nuisance dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog, the court may order the
offender to personally supervise the dog that the offender owns, keeps, or
harbors, to cause that dog to complete dog obedience training, or to do both.
(ORC 955.99(E))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Whoever commits a violation of division (d) of this section
that involves a nuisance dog is guilty of a minor misdemeanor on the first
offense and of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree on each subsequent offense
involving the same dog. Upon a person being convicted of or pleading guilty to
a third violation of division (d) of this section involving the same dog, the
court shall require the offender to register the involved dog as a dangerous
dog.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In addition to the penalties prescribed in division (l)(2)A. of
this section, if a violation of division (d) of this section involves a
nuisance dog, the court may order the offender to personally supervise the
nuisance dog that the offender owns, keeps, or harbors, to cause that dog to
complete dog obedience training, or to do both.
(ORC 955.99(F))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Whoever commits a violation of division (d) of this section that
involves a dangerous dog, or a violation of division (e) of this section is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree on a first offense and of a
misdemeanor of the third degree on each subsequent offense. Additionally, the
court may order the offender to personally supervise the dangerous dog that the
offender owns, keeps, or harbors, to cause that dog to complete dog obedience
training, or to do both, and the court may order the offender to obtain
liability insurance pursuant to division (f) of this section. The court, in the
alternative, may order the dangerous dog to be humanely destroyed by a licensed
veterinarian, the county dog warden, or the county humane society at the
ownerâs expense. With respect to a violation of division (d) of this section
that involves a dangerous dog, until the court makes a final determination and
during the pendency of any appeal of a violation of that division and at the
discretion of the dog warden, the dog shall be confined or restrained in
accordance with division (e) of this section or at the county dog pound at the
ownerâs expense.
(ORC 955.99(G))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Whoever commits a violation of division (d) of this section
that involves a vicious dog is guilty of one of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A felony to be prosecuted under appropriate state law if the
dog kills or seriously injures a person. Additionally, the court shall order

county dog warden, or the county humane society at the ownerâs expense.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A misdemeanor of the first degree if the dog causes serious
injury to a person. Additionally, the court may order the vicious dog to be
humanely destroyed by a licensed veterinarian, the county dog warden, or the
county humane society at the ownerâs expense.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the court does not order the vicious dog to be destroyed under
division (l)(5)A.2. of this section, the court shall issue an order that
specifies that Ohio R.C. 955.11(D) and divisions (e) to (j) of this section
apply with respect to the dog and the owner, keeper, or harborer of the dog as
if the dog were a dangerous dog and that Section 618.21 applies with respect to
the dog as if it were a dangerous dog. As part of the order, the court shall
order the offender to obtain the liability insurance required under division
(f)(1) of this section in an amount, exclusive of interest and costs, that
equals or exceeds one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000). Until the court
makes a final determination and during the pendency of any appeal of a
violation of division (d) of this section and at the discretion of the dog
warden, the dog shall be confined or restrained in accordance with the
provisions described in division (e) of this section or at the county dog pound
at the ownerâs expense.
(ORC 955.99(H))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (f)(2) of this section is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(ORC 955.99(J))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (g)(1), (g)(2), or (g)(3) of this section

Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (f)(1), (f)(3), or (f)(4) of this section

(ORC 955.99(M))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (j)(4) of this section is guilty of a

(ORC 955.99(N))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (10)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â If a dog is confined at the county dog pound pursuant to

618.02Â Â Â ABANDONING ANIMALS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No owner or keeper of a dog, cat, or other domestic animal shall
abandon the animal.
(ORC 959.01)
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (a) of this section is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the second degree on a first offense and a misdemeanor of the
first degree on each subsequent offense.
(ORC 959.99(E)(3))
618.03Â Â Â KILLING OR INJURING ANIMALS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall maliciously, or willfully and without the consent of
the owner, kill or injure a dog, cat, or any other domestic animal that is the
property of another. This section does not apply to a licensed veterinarian
acting in an official capacity.
(ORC 959.02)
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in this division, whoever violates
division (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree.
If the value of the animal killed or the injury done amounts to three hundred
dollars ($300.00) or more, whoever violates division (a) of this section is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(ORC 959.99(B))
618.04Â Â Â POISONING ANIMALS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall maliciously, or willfully and without the consent of
the owner, administer poison, except a licensed veterinarian acting in such
capacity, to a dog, cat, or any other domestic animal that is the property of
another; and no person shall, willfully and without the consent of the owner,
place any poisoned food where it may be easily found and eaten by any such
animal, either upon his or her own lands or the lands of another.
(ORC 959.03)
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (a) of this section is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(ORC 959.99(C))
618.05Â Â Â CRUELTY TO ANIMALS; CRUELTY TO COMPANION ANIMALS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Torture an animal, deprive one of necessary sustenance,
unnecessarily or cruelly beat, needlessly mutilate or kill, or impound or
confine an animal without supplying it during the confinement with a sufficient
quantity of good wholesome food and water;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Impound or confine an animal without affording it, during the
confinement, access to shelter from wind, rain, snow, or excessive direct
sunlight, if it can reasonably be expected that the animal would otherwise
become sick or in some other way suffer. This division does not apply to
animals impounded or confined prior to slaughter. For the purpose of this
section, âshelterâ means an artificial enclosure, windbreak, sunshade, or
natural windbreak or sunshade that is developed from the earth's contour, tree
development, or vegetation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Carry or convey an animal in a cruel or inhuman manner;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Keep animals other than cattle, poultry or fowl, swine, sheep, or
goats in an enclosure without wholesome exercise and change of air, nor feed
cows on food that produces impure or unwholesome milk;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Detain livestock in railroad cars or compartments longer than 28
hours after they are so placed without supplying them with necessary food,
water, and attention, nor permit the stock to be so crowded as to overlie,
crush, wound, or kill each other.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Upon the written request of the owner or person in custody of any
particular shipment of livestock, which written request shall be separate and
apart from any printed bill of lading or other railroad form, the length of
time in which the livestock may be detained in any cars or compartment without
food, water, and attention may be extended to 36 hours without penalty
therefor. Division (a) of this section does not prevent the dehorning of
cattle.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â All fines collected for violations of division (a) of this section
shall be paid to the society or association for the prevention of cruelty to
animals, if there is one in the municipality; otherwise, all fines shall be
paid to the general fund.
(ORC 959.13)
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Cruelty to Companion Animals.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â As used in this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â âAnimal rescue for dogs.â Has the same meaning as in R.C. Â§

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â âBoarding kennel.â Has the same meaning as in R.C. Â§ 956.01.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â âCaptive white-tailed deer.â Has the same meaning as in R.C. Â§

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â âCompanion animal.â Any animal that is kept inside a residential

Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly torture, torment, needlessly mutilate or

Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â No person who confines or who is the custodian or caretaker of a
companion animal shall negligently do any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Torture, torment, or commit an act of cruelty against the

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Deprive the companion animal of necessary sustenance or confine
the companion animal without supplying it during the confinement with
sufficient quantities of good, wholesome food and water if it can reasonably be
expected that the companion animal would become sick or suffer in any other way
as a result of or due to the deprivation or confinement;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Impound or confine the companion animal without affording it,

result of or due to the lack of adequate shelter.

Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â Notwithstanding any section of the Ohio Revised Code that otherwise

618.11Â Â Â RABIES QUARANTINE.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person having knowledge of the existence of rabies in an animal, or
knowledge that an animal has exhibited symptoms or behavior suggestive of
rabies, or knowledge that an animal has bitten any person, shall fail to
immediately report such information to the Mayor or the Chief of Police.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Whenever it is established by the Mayor or Chief of Police that any
animal has bitten any person or exhibits symptoms or behavior suggestive of
rabies, the person who owns, harbors or otherwise cares for such animal shall
confine it in close quarantine and isolation or shall place such animal in the
establishment of a veterinarian until, in either case, it is determined by the
County Board of Health that the animal is not afflicted with rabies. The
isolation and quarantine period hereby required shall be not less than ten days
from the date the person was bitten. If the animal has, or develops, any
symptoms suspicious of rabies during the ten-day period, the County Board of
Health shall be notified immediately. All expenses incurred for the keeping of
such animal, or the necessary tests to determine whether rabies exists, shall
be borne exclusively by the person who owns, harbors or otherwise cares for
such animal.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.

killed by the Chief of Police using means for such killing which are also

Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.

618.14Â Â Â CONFINING ANIMAL FOUND AT LARGE; PUBLICATION OF NOTICE; LIEN.
Â Â Â A person finding an animal at large in violation of Section
618.01 may, and a law enforcement officer of the municipality on view or
information shall, take and confine that animal, promptly giving notice of the
taking and confining of the animal to the owner or keeper, if known, and if not
known, by publishing a notice describing the animal once in a newspaper of
general circulation in the county or municipality where the animal was found.
If the owner or keeper does not appear and claim the animal and pay the
compensation prescribed in Ohio R.C. 951.13 for so taking, advertising, and
keeping it within ten days from the date of the notice, that person or the
county shall have a lien for that compensation and the animal may be sold at
public auction as provided in Ohio R.C. 1311.49. The residue of the proceeds of
sale shall be paid and deposited by the Treasurer in the General Funds of the
county.
(ORC 951.11)

618.18Â Â Â RIGHTS OF BLIND, DEAF OR HEARING IMPAIRED, OR MOBILITY IMPAIRED

Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â When either a blind, deaf or hearing impaired, or mobility impaired

amusement, or resort, and other places to which the general public is invited,
and may take the dog into such conveyances and places, subject only to the
conditions and limitations applicable to all persons not so accompanied, except
that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The dog shall not occupy a seat in any public conveyance; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The dog shall be leashed while using the facilities of a common
carrier.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Any dog in training to become an assistance dog shall be covered by
a liability insurance policy provided by the nonprofit special agency engaged
in such work protecting members of the public against personal injury or

Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â No person shall deprive a blind, deaf or hearing impaired, or mobility
impaired person, or a trainer of an assistance dog who is accompanied by an
assistance dog of any of the advantages, facilities, or privileges provided in
division (a) of this section, nor charge the person or trainer a fee or charge
for the dog.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â As used in this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â âAssistance dogâ means a guide dog, hearing dog, or service dog
that has been trained by a nonprofit special agency.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â âBlindâ means either of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Vision 20/200 or less in the better eye with proper correction;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Field defect in the better eye with proper correction that
contracts the peripheral field so that the diameter of the visual field
subtends an angle no greater than 20 degrees.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â âGuide dogâ means a dog that has been trained or is in training to
assist a blind person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â âHearing dogâ means a dog that has been trained or is in training
to assist a deaf or hearing-impaired person.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â "Institutions of education" means:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any state university or college as defined in Ohio R.C.Â 3345.32;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any private college or university that holds a certificate of

1713;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any elementary or secondary school operated by a board of

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any chartered or nonchartered nonpublic elementary or secondary
school; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any school issued a certificate of registration by the state
Board of Career Colleges and Schools.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â âMobility impaired personâ means any person, regardless of age, who
is subject to a physiological defect or deficiency regardless of its cause,
nature, or extent that renders the person unable to move about without the aid

personâs functional ability to ambulate, climb, descend, sit, rise, or perform

neurological or psychological disability that limits the personâs functional
ability to ambulate, climb, descend, sit, rise, or perform any related

Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â âService dogâ means a dog that has been trained or is in training

(ORCÂ 955.43)

618.19Â Â Â FARM ANIMALS, BEES AND FOWL.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall keep, harbor or maintain farm animals, bees or fowl
within the Village on properties containing less than four acres. The four
acres or more must be contiguous, held in single ownership, and must be the
acreage upon which the farm animals, bees or fowl are kept.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Provided that the acreage requirements as set forth in division (a) of
this section are met, no person shall keep any farm animals, bees or fowl in
any pen, yard, lot or other enclosure which is situated within 50 feet of an
adjacent property line and 100 feet of an inhabited dwelling house or
commercial or industrial building, other than one which is inhabited by the
owner of such farm animals, bees or fowl.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Farm animals, bees and fowl shall be properly confined without the use
of electric fencing.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Before stabling or keeping any farm animals, bees or fowl, provided
that the acreage requirements and the distance requirements herein are met, a
written application shall be made to the Village for permission to do so. If
the permit is granted by the Village Manager, a fee of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) shall be charged.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â Any premises involved in the stabling or keeping of farm animals, bees
or fowl must be maintained in a clean and sanitary manner. Upon complaint or
objectionable odors emanating from such premises, by neighbors, the permit may
be revolved by the Village Manager.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â Whoever violates any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a
minor misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 00-4-4. Passed 4-27-00; Ord. 22-02-01. Passed 2-15-22.)
618.20Â Â Â WILD OR EXOTIC ANIMALS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall market, at wholesale or retail, any wild or exotic
animal or furbearing quadruped. Exceptions to this prohibition include those
animals native to the farm and sold at auction or by private sale, such as
horses, cattle, swine and poultry, and those animals sold by pet dealers or by
private sale, such as domestic cats, domestic dogs, domestic rabbits, guinea
pigs, chinchillas, mice, hamsters, gerbils, domestic birds and nonpoisonous,
noncarnivorous fish.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â "Wild or exotic animal" means an animal which generally lives in its
original and natural state and is not normally domesticated.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â No person shall keep, harbor or market, at wholesale or retail, any
poisonous reptile. Any person who presently keeps or harbors a poisonous
reptile, may keep the same until its death or until its possession is
transferred outside of the Village. However, no such person shall keep any such
reptile unless he or she registers the same with the Mayor or his or her
designee.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Exceptions to these prohibitions are touring animal exhibitions,
circuses, veterinarians (for the purpose of medical treatment), educational
research facilities, aid for handicapped persons or persons licensed or
permitted by the State of Ohio.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â Permission may be given by the Mayor or his or her designee for a
person to temporarily keep, care for or protect a wild animal native to the
State of Ohio which has been deemed to be homeless, provided it is under the
care of a licensed veterinarian.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â Any animal or reptile found to be in violation of this section may be
impounded by the County Dog Warden and placed in a designated shelter or with a
licensed veterinarian. The expenses of impounding, maintenance and destruction
of such animal or reptile shall be the responsibility of the owner or other
such person having charge or control of such animal or reptile.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â Whoever violates any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a
minor misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 00-4-5. Passed 4-27-00.)
618.21Â Â Â RESTRICTIONS ON DOG OWNERSHIP FOR CERTAIN CONVICTED FELONS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person who is convicted of or pleads guilty to a felony offense of
violence committed on or after May 22, 2012 or a felony violation of any
provision of Ohio R.C. Chapter 959, Ohio R.C. Chapter 2923 or Ohio R.C. Chapter
2925 committed on or after May 22, 2012 shall knowingly own, possess, have
custody of, or reside in a residence with either of the following for a period
of three years commencing either upon the date of release of the person from
any period of incarceration imposed for the offense or violation or, if the
person is not incarcerated for the offense or violation, upon the date of the
personâs final release from the other sanctions imposed for the offense or
violation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â An unspayed or unneutered dog older than 12 weeks of age;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Any dog that has been determined to be a dangerous dog under Ohio
R.C. Chapter 955 or any substantially equivalent municipal ordinance.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â A person described in division (a) of this section shall microchip for
permanent identification any dog owned, possessed by, or in the custody of the
person.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Division (a) of this section does not apply to any person who is
confined in a correctional institution of the Department of Rehabilitation and
Correction.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Division (a) of this section does not apply to any person with
respect to any dog that the person owned, possessed, had custody of, or resided
in a residence with prior to May 22, 2012.
(ORC 955.54)
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (a) or (b) of this section is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
(ORC 955.99(O))
618.22 SEXUAL CONDUCT WITH AN ANIMAL.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â As used in this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â âAnimalâ. Means a nonhuman mammal, bird, reptile, or amphibian,
either dead or alive.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â âOffense.â Means a violation of this section or an attempt, in
violation of R.C. Â§ 2923.02, to violate this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â âOfficer.â Has the same meaning as in R.C. Â§ 959.132.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â âSexual conduct.â Means either of the following committed for the
purpose of sexual gratification:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any act done between a person and animal that involves contact of
the penis of one and the vulva of the other, the penis of one and the penis of
the other, the penis of one and the anus of the other, the mouth of one and the
penis of the other, the mouth of one and the anus of the other, the vulva of
one and the vulva of the other, the mouth of one and the vulva of the other,
any other contact between a reproductive organ of one and a reproductive organ
of the other, or any other insertion of a reproductive organ of one into an
orifice of the other;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Without a bona fide veterinary or animal husbandry purpose to do
so, the insertion, however slight, of any part of a personâs body or any
instrument, apparatus, or other object into the vaginal, anal, or reproductive
opening of an animal.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly engage in sexual conduct with an animal or
knowingly possess, sell, or purchase an animal with the intent that it be
subjected to sexual conduct.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly organize, promote, aid, or abet in the
conduct of an act involving any sexual conduct with an animal.
(R.C. Â§ 959.21)
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the
second degree. In addition, the court may order the offender to forfeit the
animal or livestock and may provide for its disposition including but not
limited to the sale of the animal or livestock. If an animal or livestock is
forfeited and sold pursuant to this division, the proceeds from the sale first
shall be applied to pay the expenses incurred with regard to the care of the
animal from the time it was taken from the custody of the former owner. The
balance of the proceeds from the sale, if any, shall be paid to the former
owner of the animal.
(ORC 959.99(D))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If a court has reason to believe that a person who is convicted of
or pleads guilty to a violation of this section suffers from a mental or
emotional disorder that contributed to the violation, the court may impose as a
community control sanction or as a condition of probation a requirement that
the offender undergo psychological evaluation or counseling. The court shall
order the offender to pay the costs of the evaluation or counseling.
(ORC 959.99(E)(7))

624.02Â Â Â ADULT USE CANNABIS CONTROL; LIMITATIONS ON CONDUCT BY INDIVIDUALS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in R.C. Chapter 3780 and notwithstanding
any conflicting provision of this code or the Ohio Revised Code, an adult use
consumer, may do the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Use adult use cannabis;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Possess, transfer without remuneration to another adult consumer,
or transport adult use cannabis, subject to division (b) of this section; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Purchase adult use cannabis from an adult use dispensary per day in
amounts that do not exceed the possession limits set forth in division (b)(1)
of this section.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in R.C. Chapter 3796:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The amount of cannabis that may be possessed by an adult use
consumer shall not exceed:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Two and one-half ounces of adult use cannabis in any form except
adult use extract; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Fifteen grams of adult use cannabis in the form of adult use
extract.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The amount of cannabis that may be transferred by an adult use
consumer without remuneration and not advertised or promoted to the public
shall not exceed:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Two and one-half ounces of adult use cannabis in any form except
adult use extract; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Fifteen grams of adult use cannabis in the form of adult use
extract.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The amount of cannabis that may be transported by an adult use
consumer shall not exceed:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Two and one-half ounces of adult use cannabis in any form except
adult use extract; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Fifteen grams of adult use cannabis in the form of adult use
extract.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in R.C. Chapter 3780, an adult use
consumer shall not be subject to arrest, criminal prosecution, or civil penalty
for engaging in any of the activities authorized under R.C. Chapter 3780,
including:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Obtaining, using, possessing, or transporting adult use cannabis;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Performing conduct authorized under R.C. Â§ 3780.29;
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Acquiring, possessing, using, purchasing, manufacturing, selling,
or transporting paraphernalia; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Assisting another adult use consumer, or allowing property to be
used, in any of the acts authorized by R.C. Chapter 3780.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â An individual is prohibited from operating a vehicle, motor
vehicle, streetcar, trackless trolley, bike, watercraft, or aircraft while
using adult use cannabis or while under the influence of adult use cannabis and
is subject to R.C. Â§ 4511.19 or a substantially equivalent municipal ordinance
for any violation of this division.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â An individual is prohibited from smoking, vaporizing, or using any
other combustible adult use cannabis product while in a vehicle, motor vehicle,
streetcar, trackless trolley, bike, watercraft, or aircraft and is subject to
R.C. Â§ 4511.19 or a substantially equivalent municipal ordinance for any
violation of this division.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in R.C. Chapter 3780, no individual under
21 years of age shall knowingly show or give false information concerning the
individualâs name, age, or other identification for the purpose of purchasing
adult use cannabis from an adult use dispensary licensed under R.C. Chapter
3780.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â Nothing in R.C. Chapter 3780 is intended to permit the transfer or
sale of adult use cannabis, with or without remuneration, to an individual
under 21 years of age, or to allow an individual under 21 years of age to
purchase, possess, use, process, transport, or cultivate cannabis except where
authorized by R.C. Chapter 3796.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â It is unlawful for any parent or guardian to knowingly permit their
residence, any other private property under their control, or any vehicle,
conveyance, or watercraft under their control to be used by an invitee of the
parentâs child or the guardianâs ward, if the invitee is under 21 years of age,
in a manner that constitutes a violation of R.C. Chapter 3780.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â A parent or guardian is deemed to have knowingly permitted their
residence, any other private property under their control, or any vehicle,
conveyance, or watercraft under their control to be used in violation of R.C.
Chapter 3780 if they knowingly authorize or permit consumption of cannabis by
underage invitees.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Where the residence or other property has an owner and a tenant or
lessee, the trier of fact may infer that the residence or other property is
occupied only by the tenant or lessee.
(R.C. Â§ 3780.36)
Â Â Â (h)Â Â Â Penalties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in R.C. Chapter 3796, R.C. Â§ 2925.11
or a substantially equivalent municipal ordinance shall apply when an adult use
consumer possesses an amount of cannabis greater than the limits set forth in
division (b)(1) of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in R.C. Chapter 3780, an adult use
consumer who uses adult use cannabis in public areas, or who violates division
(d)(2) of this section as a passenger, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An individual under 21 years of age who knowingly shows or
gives false information concerning the individualâs name, age, or other
identification for the purpose of purchasing or otherwise obtaining adult use
cannabis from an adult use dispensary licensed under R.C. Chapter 3780 is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. If, in committing a first
violation, the offender presented to an adult use dispensary licensed under
R.C. Chapter 3780 a false, fictitious, or altered identification card, a false
or fictitious driverâs license purportedly issued by any state, or a driverâs
license issued by any state that has been altered, the offender is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not less than $250 and not
more than $1,000, and may be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of not more
than six months.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â On a second violation in which, for the second time, the offender
presented to an adult use dispensary licensed under R.C. Chapter 3780 a false,
fictitious, or altered identification card, a false or fictitious driverâs
license purportedly issued by any state, or a driverâs license issued by any
state that has been altered, the offender is guilty of a misdemeanor of the
first degree and shall be fined not less than $500 nor more than $1,000, and
may be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of not more than six months. The
court also may impose a class seven suspension of the offenderâs driverâs or
commercial driverâs license or permit or nonresident operating privilege from
the range specified in R.C. Â§ 4510.02(A)(7). The court, in lieu of suspending
the offenderâs temporary instruction permit, probationary driverâs license, or
driverâs license, instead may order the offender to perform a determinate
number of hours of community service, with the court determining the actual
number of hours and the nature of the community service the offender shall
perform.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â On a third or subsequent violation in which, for the third or
subsequent time, the offender presented to an adult use dispensary licensed
under R.C. Chapter 3780 a false, fictitious, or altered identification card, a
false or fictitious driverâs license purportedly issued by any state, or a
driverâs license issued by any state that has been altered, the offender is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not less than
$500 nor more than $1,000, and may be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of
not more than six months. Except as provided in this division, the court also
may impose a class six suspension of the offenderâs driverâs or commercial
driverâs license or permit or nonresident operating privilege from the range
specified in R.C. Â§ 4510.02(A)(6), and the court may order that the suspension
or denial remain in effect until the offender attains the age of 21 years. The
court, in lieu of suspending the offenderâs temporary instruction permit,
probationary driverâs license, or driverâs license, instead may order the
offender to perform a determinate number of hours of community service, with
the court determining the actual number of hours and the nature of the
community service the offender shall perform.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â An individual who is under 21 years of age and who solicits another
individual to purchase adult use cannabis from an adult use dispensary licensed
under R.C. Chapter 3780 is guilty of:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â For a first violation, a misdemeanor of the fourth degree; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For a second or subsequent violation, a misdemeanor of the second
degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â An employee or agent of an adult use dispensary licensed under R.C.
Chapter 3780 who knowingly sells cannabis to an individual under 21 years of
age is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Any individual who violates R.C. Â§ 3780.10(A), or R.C. Â§ 3780.29
(F), is guilty of the illegal trafficking in drugs under R.C. Â§ 2925.03 and the
illegal manufacture of drugs under R.C. Â§ 2925.04.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Any individual who violates division (b)(2) or (b)(3) of this
section guilty of the illegal trafficking in drugs under R.C. Â§ 2925.03.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â Any individual who violates R.C. Â§ 3780.20(B) is guilty of illegal
dispensing of drug samples under R.C. Â§ 2925.36 or a substantially equivalent
municipal ordinance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An individual who violates division (g) of this section is
guilty of:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â For a first violation, a misdemeanor of the third degree; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â For a second or subsequent violation, a misdemeanor of the
first degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If a violation of division (g) of this section directly or
indirectly results in great bodily harm or death to any individual, the
individual violating division (g) is guilty of a felony to be prosecuted under
appropriate state law.
(R.C. Â§ 3780.99)
624.025Â Â Â CULTIVATION OF MARIHUANA.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly cultivate marihuana.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â This section does not apply to any person listed in Ohio R.C. 2925.03
(B)(1), (2) or (3), or a substantially equivalent municipal ordinance, to the
extent and under the circumstances described in that division.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Whoever commits a violation of division (a) of this section is guilty
of illegal cultivation of marihuana.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in the following divisions, illegal
cultivation of marihuana is a minor misdemeanor or, if the offense was
committed in the vicinity of a school or in the vicinity of a juvenile, a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If the amount of marihuana involved equals or exceeds 100 grams but
is less than 200 grams, illegal cultivation of marihuana is a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree or, if the offense was committed in the vicinity of a school
or in the vicinity of a juvenile, a misdemeanor of the third degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â If the amount of marihuana involved equals or exceeds 200 grams,
illegal cultivation of marihuana is a felony to be prosecuted under appropriate
State law.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Arrest or conviction for a minor misdemeanor violation of this section
does not constitute a criminal record and need not be reported by the person so
arrested or convicted in response to any inquiries about the person's criminal
record, including any inquiries contained in any application for employment,
license, or other right or privilege, or made in connection with the person's
appearance as a witness.
(R.C. Â§ 2925.04(A), (B), (C)(5), (G))
624.03Â Â Â DRUG POSSESSION OFFENSES.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly obtain, possess, or use a controlled
substance or a controlled substance analog.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â This section does not apply to any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Manufacturers, licensed health professionals authorized to
prescribe drugs, pharmacists, owners of pharmacies, and other persons whose
conduct is in accordance with R.C. Chapters 3719, 4715, 4723, 4729, 4730, 4731,
4741, and 4772.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the offense involves an anabolic steroid, any person who is
conducting or participating in a research project involving the use of an
anabolic steroid if the project has been approved by the United States Food and
Drug Administration.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any person who sells, offers for sale, prescribes, dispenses, or
administers for livestock or other nonhuman species an anabolic steroid that is
expressly intended for administration through implants to livestock or other
nonhuman species and approved for that purpose under the Federal Food, Drug,
and Cosmetic Act, and is sold, offered for sale, prescribed, dispensed, or
administered for that purpose in accordance with that Act.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any person who obtained the controlled substance pursuant to a
prescription issued by a licensed health professional authorized to prescribe
drugs if the prescription was issued for a legitimate medical purpose and not
altered, forged, or obtained through deception or commission of a theft
offense. As used in this division (b)(1)D., âdeceptionâ and âtheft offenseâ
have the same meanings as in R.C. Â§ 2913.01.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â As used in division (b)(2) of this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â âCommunity addiction services provider.â Has the same meaning
as in Ohio R.C. 5119.01.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â âCommunity control sanction.â Has the same meanings as in Ohio
R.C. 2929.01
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â âHealth care facility.â Has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C.
2919.16.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â âMinor drug possession offense.â A violation of this section
or Ohio R.C. 2925.11 that is a misdemeanor or a felony of the fifth degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â âPeace officer.â Has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C. 2935.01.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â âPost-release control sanction.â Has the same meaning as in
Ohio R.C. 2967.28.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â âPublic agency.â Has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C. 2930.01.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â âQualified individual.â A person who is acting in good faith
who seeks or obtains medical assistance for another person who is experiencing
a drug overdose, a person who experiences a drug overdose and who seeks medical
assistance for that overdose, or a person who is the subject of another person
seeking or obtaining medical assistance for that overdose as described in

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â âSeek or obtain medical assistance.â Includes, but is not

on-duty peace officer, or transporting or presenting a person to a health care

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Subject to division (b)(2)E. of this section, a qualified
individual shall not be arrested, charged, prosecuted, convicted, or penalized

R.C. Â§ 2925.12, R.C. Â§ 2925.14(C)(1), or R.C. Â§ 2925.141 if all of the
following apply:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The evidence of the obtaining, possession, or use of the
controlled substance or controlled substance analog, drug abuse instruments, or
drug paraphernalia that would be the basis of the offense was obtained as a
result of the qualified individual seeking the medical assistance or
experiencing an overdose and needing medical assistance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Subject to division (b)(2)F. of this section, within 30 days
after seeking or obtaining the medical assistance, the qualified individual
seeks and obtains a screening and receives a referral for treatment from a
community addiction services provider or a properly credentialed addiction
treatment professional.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Subject to division (b)(2)F. of this section, the qualified
individual who obtains a screening and receives a referral for treatment under

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If a person who is serving a community control sanction or is

this section, then R.C. Â§ 2929.141(B), R.C. Â§ 2929.15(B)(2), R.C. Â§ 2929.25(D)

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Nothing in division (b)(2)B. of this section shall be construed
to do any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Limit the admissibility of any evidence in connection with the

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Limit any seizure of evidence or contraband otherwise

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Limit or abridge the authority of a peace officer to detain or

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Limit, modify, or remove any immunity from liability available
pursuant to law in effect prior to September 13, 2016 to any public agency or
to an employee of any public agency.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Division (b)(2)B. of this section does not apply to any person
who twice previously has been granted an immunity under division (b)(2)B. of
this section. No person shall be granted an immunity under division (b)(2)B. of
this section more than two times.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Nothing in this section shall compel any qualified individual to

requirements of the âHealth Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of
1996â, 104 Pub. L. No. 191, 110 Stat. 2021, 42 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1320d et seq., as
amended, and regulations promulgated by the United States Department of Health
and Human Services to implement the act or the requirements of 42 C.F.R. part
2.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (a) of this section is guilty of one of the
following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â If the drug involved in the violation is a compound, mixture,
preparation, or substance included in Schedule I or Schedule II, with the
exception of marihuana or hashish, whoever violates division (a) of this
section is guilty of a felony to be prosecuted under appropriate state law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If the drug involved in the violation is a compound, mixture,
preparation, or substance included in Schedule III, Schedule IV, or Schedule V,
whoever violates division (a) of this section is guilty of possession of drugs.
The penalty for the offense shall be determined as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in division (c)(2)B. of this
section, possession of drugs is a misdemeanor of the first degree or, if the
offender previously has been convicted of a drug abuse offense, a felony to be
prosecuted under appropriate state law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the amount of the drug involved equals or exceeds the bulk
amount, possession of drugs is a felony to be prosecuted under appropriate
state law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â If the drug involved in the violation is marihuana or a compound,
mixture, preparation, or substance containing marihuana other than hashish,
whoever violates division (a) of this section is guilty of possession of
marihuana. The penalty for the offense shall be determined as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in division (c)(3)B. or (c)(3)C. of
this section, possession of marihuana is a minor misdemeanor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the amount of the drug involved equals or exceeds 100 grams
but is less than 200 grams, possession of marihuana is a misdemeanor of the
fourth degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If the amount of the drug involved equals or exceeds 200 grams,
possession of marihuana is a felony to be prosecuted under appropriate state
law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â If the drug involved in the violation is hashish or a compound,
mixture, preparation, or substance containing hashish, whoever violates
division (a) of this section is guilty of possession of hashish. The penalty
for the offense shall be determined as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in division (c)(4)B. or (c)(4)C. of
this section, possession of hashish is a minor misdemeanor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the amount of the drug involved equals or exceeds five grams
but is less than ten grams of hashish in a solid form or equals or exceeds one
gram but is less than two grams of hashish in a liquid concentrate, liquid
extract, or liquid distillate form, possession of hashish is a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If the amount of the drug involved equals or exceeds ten grams of
hashish in a solid form or equals or exceeds two grams of hashish in a liquid
concentrate, liquid extract, or liquid distillate form, possession of hashish
is a felony to be prosecuted under appropriate state law.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â If the drug involved in the violation is a compound, mixture,
preparation, or substance that is a combination of a fentanyl-related compound
and marihuana, one of the following applies:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in division (c)(5)B. of this
section, the offender is guilty of possession of marihuana and shall be
punished as provided in division (c)(3) of this section. Except as otherwise
provided in division (c)(5)B. of this section, the offender is not guilty of
possession of a fentanyl-related compound under R.C. Â§ 2925.11(C)(11) and shall
not be charged with, convicted of, or punished under R.C. Â§ 2925.11(C)(11) for
possession of a fentanyl-related compound.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the offender knows or has reason to know that the compound,
mixture, preparation, or substance that is the drug involved contains a
fentanyl-related compound, the offender is guilty of possession of a fentanyl-
related compound and shall be punished under R.C. Â§ 2925.11(C)(11).
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â If the drug involved in the violation is a compound, mixture,
preparation, or substance that is a combination of a fentanyl-related compound
and any Schedule III, Schedule IV, or Schedule V controlled substance that is
not a fentanyl-related compound, one of the following applies:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Except as otherwise provided in division (c)(6)B. of this
section, the offender is guilty of possession of drugs and shall be punished as
provided in division (c)(2) of this section. Except as otherwise provided in
division (c)(6)B. of this section, the offender is not guilty of possession of
a fentanyl-related compound under R.C. Â§ 2925.11(C)(11) and shall not be
charged with, convicted of, or punished under R.C. Â§ 2925.11(C)(11) for
possession of a fentanyl-related compound.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the offender knows or has reason to know that the compound,
mixture, preparation, or substance that is the drug involved contains a
fentanyl-related compound, the offender is guilty of possession of a fentanyl-
related compound and shall be punished under R.C. Â§ 2925.11(C)(11).
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Arrest or conviction for a minor misdemeanor violation of this section
does not constitute a criminal record and need not be reported by the person so
arrested or convicted in response to any inquiries about the person's criminal
record, including any inquiries contained in any application for employment,
license, or other right or privilege, or made in connection with the person's
appearance as a witness.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â In addition to any prison term or jail term authorized or required by
division (c) of this section and R.C. Â§Â§ 2929.13, 2929.14, 2929.22, 2929.24,
and 2929.25, or any substantially equivalent municipal ordinance, and in
addition to any other sanction that is imposed for the offense under this
section, R.C. Â§Â§ 2929.11 through 2929.18, or R.C. Â§Â§ 2929.21 through 2929.28,
or any substantially equivalent municipal ordinance, if applicable, the court
shall also do the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â If the offender is a professionally licensed person, in addition to
any other sanction imposed for a violation of this section, the court
immediately shall comply with R.C. Â§ 2925.38.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If the offender has a driverâs or commercial driverâs license or
permit, R.C. Â§ 2929.33 applies.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Any offender who received a mandatory suspension of the
offenderâs driverâs or commercial driverâs license or permit under this section

Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Upon the filing of a motion under division (f) of this section, the

624.05Â Â Â PERMITTING DRUG ABUSE.

Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Whoever violates this section is guilty of permitting drug abuse.

Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â If the offender is a professionally licensed person, in addition

624.06Â Â Â USE OR POSSESSION OF PARAPHERNALIA.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â As used in this section, "drug paraphernalia" means any equipment,
product, or material of any kind that is used by the offender, intended by the
offender for use, or designed for use, in propagating, cultivating, growing,
harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing,
preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing,
concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introduced into the
human body, a controlled substance in violation of this chapter. "Drug
paraphernalia" includes, but is not limited to, any of the following equipment,
products, or materials that are used by the offender, intended by the offender
for use, or designed by the offender for use, in any of the following manners:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â A kit for propagating, cultivating, growing, or harvesting any
species of a plant that is a controlled substance or from which a controlled
substance can be derived.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â A kit for manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing,
processing, or preparing a controlled substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Any object, instrument, or device for manufacturing, compounding,
converting, producing, processing, or preparing methamphetamine.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â An isomerization device for increasing the potency of any species
of a plant that is a controlled substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Testing equipment for identifying, or analyzing the strength,
effectiveness, or purity of, a controlled substance, except for those exempted
in division (d)(4) of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â A scale or balance for weighing or measuring a controlled
substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â A diluent or adulterant, such as quinine hydrochloride, mannitol,
mannite, dextrose, or lactose, for cutting a controlled substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â A separation gin or sifter for removing twigs and seeds from, or
otherwise cleaning or refining, marihuana.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â A blender, bowl, container, spoon, or mixing device for compounding
a controlled substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (10)Â Â Â A capsule, balloon, envelope, or container for packaging small
quantities of a controlled substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (11)Â Â Â A container or device for storing or concealing a controlled
substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (12)Â Â Â A hypodermic syringe, needle, or instrument for parenterally
injecting a controlled substance into the human body.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (13)Â Â Â An object, instrument, or device for ingesting, inhaling, or
otherwise introducing into the human body, marihuana, cocaine, hashish, or
hashish oil, such as a metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or
ceramic pipe, with or without a screen, permanent screen, hashish head, or
punctured metal bowl; water pipe; carburetion tube or device; smoking or
carburetion mask; roach clip or similar object used to hold burning material,
such as a marihuana cigarette, that has become too small or too short to be
held in the hand; miniature cocaine spoon, or cocaine vial; chamber pipe;
carburetor pipe; electric pipe; air driver pipe; chillum; bong; or ice pipe or
chiller.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â In determining if any equipment, product, or material is drug
paraphernalia, a court or law enforcement officer shall consider, in addition
to other relevant factors, the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Any statement by the owner or by anyone in control of the
equipment, product, or material, concerning its use.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â The proximity in time or space of the equipment, product, or
material, or of the act relating to the equipment, product, or material, to a
violation of any provision of this chapter or Ohio R.C. Chapter 2925.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â The proximity of the equipment, product, or material to any
controlled substance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â The existence of any residue of a controlled substance on the
equipment, product, or material.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of the owner, or of
anyone in control, of the equipment, product, or material, to deliver it to any
person whom he or she knows intends to use the equipment, product, or material
to facilitate a violation of any provision of this chapter or Ohio R.C. Chapter
2925. A finding that the owner or anyone in control of the equipment, product,
or material is not guilty of a violation of any other provision of this chapter
or Ohio R.C. Chapter 2925 does not prevent a finding that the equipment,
product, or material was intended or designed by the offender for use as drug
paraphernalia.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Any oral or written instruction provided with the equipment,
product, or material concerning its use.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Any descriptive material accompanying the equipment, product, or
material and explaining or depicting its use.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â National or local advertising concerning the use of the equipment,
product, or material.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â The manner and circumstances in which the equipment, product, or
material is displayed for sale.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (10)Â Â Â Direct or circumstantial evidence of the ratio of the sales of the
equipment, product, or material to the total sales of the business enterprise.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (11)Â Â Â The existence and scope of legitimate uses of the equipment,
product, or material in the community.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (12)Â Â Â Expert testimony concerning the use of the equipment, product, or
material.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Subject to divisions (d)(2), (d)(3), and (d)(4) of this section,
no person shall knowingly use, or possess with purpose to use, drug
paraphernalia.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly sell, or possess or manufacture with
purpose to sell, drug paraphernalia, if he or she knows or reasonably should
know that the equipment, product, or material will be used as drug
paraphernalia.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â No person shall place an advertisement in any newspaper, magazine,
handbill, or other publication that is published and printed and circulates
primarily within this State, if he or she knows that the purpose of the
advertisement is to promote the illegal sale in this Municipality or in this
State of the equipment, product, or material that the offender intended or
designed for use as drug paraphernalia.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â This section does not apply to manufacturers, licensed health
professionals authorized to prescribe drugs, pharmacists, owners of pharmacies
and other persons whose conduct is in accordance with R.C. Chapters 3719, 4715,
4723, 4729, 4730, 4731, 4741, and 4772. This section shall not be construed to
prohibit the possession or use of a hypodermic as authorized by R.C. Â§
3719.172.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Division (c)(1) of this section does not apply to a personâs use,
or possession with purpose to use, any drug paraphernalia that is equipment, a
product, or material of any kind that is used by the person, intended by the
person for use, or designed for use in storing, containing, concealing,
injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body
marihuana.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Division (B)(2) of R.C. Â§ 2925.11 applies with respect to a
violation of division (c)(1) of this section when a person seeks or obtains
medical assistance for another person who is experiencing a drug overdose, a
person experiences a drug overdose and seeks medical assistance for that
overdose, or a person is the subject of another person seeking or obtaining
medical assistance for that overdose.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Division (c)(1) of this section does not apply to a personâs use,
or possession with purpose to use, any drug testing strips to determine the
presence of fentanyl or a fentanyl-related compound.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â Notwithstanding Ohio R.C. 2981, any drug paraphernalia that was used,
possessed, sold, or manufactured in violation of this section shall be seized,
after a conviction for that violation, shall be forfeited, and upon forfeiture
shall be disposed of pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2981.12(B).
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (c)(1) of this section is guilty of
illegal use or possession of drug paraphernalia, a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Except as provided in division (f)(3) of this section, whoever
violates division (c)(2) of this section is guilty of dealing in drug
paraphernalia, a misdemeanor of the second degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (c)(2) of this section by selling drug
paraphernalia to a juvenile is guilty of selling drug paraphernalia to
juveniles, a misdemeanor of the first degree.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Whoever violates division (c)(3) of this section is guilty of
illegal advertising of drug paraphernalia, a misdemeanor of the second degree.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â If the offender is a professionally licensed person, in addition
to any other sanction imposed for a violation of this section, the court
immediately shall comply with R.C. Â§ 2925.38.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If the offender has a driverâs or commercial driverâs license or
permit, R.C. Â§ 2929.33.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any offender who received a mandatory suspension of the
offenderâs driverâs or commercial driverâs license or permit under this section
prior to September 13, 2016 may file a motion with the sentencing court
requesting the termination of the suspension. However, an offender who pleaded
guilty to or was convicted of a violation of Ohio R.C. 4511.19 or a
substantially equivalent municipal ordinance or law of another state or the
United States that arose out of the same set of circumstances as the violation
for which the offenderâs license or permit was suspended under this section
shall not file such a motion.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Upon the filing of a motion under division (g)(3) of this
section, the sentencing court, in its discretion, may terminate the suspension.
(ORC 2925.14)
Â Â Â (h)Â Â Â Illegal use or possession of marihuana drug paraphernalia.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â As used in this division (h), âdrug paraphernaliaâ has the same
meaning as in division (a) of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â In determining if any equipment, product, or material is drug
paraphernalia, a court or law enforcement officer shall consider, in addition
to other relevant factors, all factors identified in division (b) of this
section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly use, or possess with purpose to use, any
drug paraphernalia that is equipment, a product, or material of any kind that
is used by the person, intended by the person for use, or designed for use in
storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise
introducing into the human body marihuana.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â This division (h) does not apply to any person identified in
division (d)(1) of this section, and it shall not be construed to prohibit the
possession or use of a hypodermic as authorized by Ohio R.C. 3719.172.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Division (e) of this section applies with respect to any drug
paraphernalia that was used or possessed in violation of division (h) of this

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Division (B)(2) of R.C. Â§ 2925.11 applies with respect to a
violation of this division (h) when a person seeks or obtains medical
assistance for another person who is experiencing a drug overdose, a person
experiences a drug overdose and seeks medical assistance for that overdose, or
a person is the subject of another person seeking or obtaining medical
assistance for that overdose.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Whoever violates division (h)(3) of this section is guilty of
illegal use or possession of marihuana drug paraphernalia, a minor misdemeanor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Arrest or conviction for a violation of division (h)(3) of this
section does not constitute a criminal record and need not be reported by the
person so arrested or convicted in response to any inquiries about the personâs

the personâs appearance as a witness.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In addition to any other sanction imposed upon an offender for
a violation of division (h) of this section, the court shall do the following,
if applicable:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â If the offender pleaded guilty to or was convicted of a
violation of R.C. Â§ 4511.19 or a substantially similar municipal ordinance or

or commercial driverâs license or permit for not more than five years.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the offender is a professionally licensed person, the court

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any offender who received a mandatory suspension of the
offenderâs driverâs or commercial driverâs license or permit under division (h)

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Upon the filing of a motion under division (h)(7)B. of this

624.07Â Â Â ABUSING HARMFUL INTOXICANTS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Except for lawful research, clinical, medical, dental, or veterinary

Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Whoever violates this section is guilty of abusing harmful

Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â If the offender is a professionally licensed person, in addition

Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â If the offender has a driver's or commercial driver's license or
permit, R.C. Â§ 2929.33 applies.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any offender who received a mandatory suspension of the
offenderâs driverâs or commercial driverâs license or permit under this section
