1020.01Â Â Â CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO IMPROVING STREETS.
Â Â Â No department of the Municipality shall accept, lay out, open, improve,
grade, pave, curb or light any street or other way, unless the street or way
has been accepted or opened or otherwise has received the legal status of a
public street or way prior to the effective date of this chapter, or unless the
street or way corresponds in location and extent with a street or way shown on
a recorded plat which has been legally accepted by Council.
1020.02Â Â Â EXCAVATIONS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Permit Required. No person, other than an authorized Municipal
official or the authorized employees or agents of such Municipal official,
shall make any opening in any street, alley, sidewalk or public way of the
Municipality unless a permit to make the opening has been obtained prior to
commencement of the work.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Application and Cash Deposit. Each permit for making an opening shall
be confined to a single project and shall be issued by the Mayor or other
proper Municipal officer. Application shall be made on a form prescribed by
Council, giving the exact location of the proposed opening, the kind of paying,
the area and depth to be excavated and such other fact as may be provided for.
The permit shall be issued only after a cash deposit sufficient to cover the
cost of restoration has been posted with the Mayor or other proper Municipal
officer, conditioned upon prompt and satisfactory refilling of excavations and
restoration of all surfaces disturbed.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Restoration of Payment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The opening and restoration of pavement or other surface shall be
performed under the direction and to the satisfaction of an authorized
Municipal official, and in accordance with rules, regulations, and
specification approved by Council.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Upon failure or refusal of the permittee satisfactorily to fill the
excavation, restore the surface and remove all excess materials within the time
specified in the permit or, where not specified therein, within a reasonable
time after commencement of the work, the Municipality may proceed without
notice to make such fill and restoration, and the deposit referred to in
subsection (b) hereof shall be deemed forfeited. Thereupon, the deposit shall
be paid into the Street Repair Fund of the Municipality, except such part
demanded and paid to the permittee as the difference between the deposit and
the charges of the Municipality for restoration services performed by it. If
the amount of such services performed by the Municipality should exceed the
amount of the deposit, the ClerkâTreasurer or other proper Municipal officer
shall proceed to collect the remainder due from such permittee.
1020.03Â Â Â CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO CONSTRUCTION OF DRIVEWAYS OR DRAINAGE PIPES
UNDER DRIVEWAYS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Before the issuance of a zoning permit, the owner of a parcel of real
property, or his or her agent, upon which the construction of a driveway
entrance, driveway or the installation of a drainage pipe under a driveway
shall be undertaken, shall deposit the cash sum of seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) within the Village Clerk, or a bond in the like amount given by a
qualified and recognized insurance carrier/bonding company as is determined by
the Village, for the purpose of securing the restoration and integrity of the
roads of the Village when construction of, at, or on a driveway entrance,
driveway or a drainage pipe under a driveway is contemplated.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â The real property owner and his or her agent performing the
construction shall follow all guidelines of installation as may be required by
the Village.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â The cash deposit of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or a
qualified bond in a like amount, shall be released within 30 days from
notification to the Village of the construction completion as set forth above,
and an inspection of same by the Street Superintendent of the Village, less any
appropriate deduction therefrom for any additional restoration costs which may
be required by the Street Superintendent of the Village.
(Ord. 01-3-5. Passed 3-13-01.)
1020.04Â Â Â DEPOSIT PROCEDURE TO SECURE RESTORATION OF LAND FOLLOWING THE
COMPLETION OF CONSTRUCTION IN THE ROADS RIGHTS-OF-WAY.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â There is hereby established a deposit fee in the amount of five
hundred dollars ($500.00), cash, to secure restoration of the lands disturbed
by construction in the roads rights-of-way within the Village. The deposit
shall be paid to the Village Clerk at the time that a permit application is
submitted to perform such construction. No construction permit shall be issued
without the applicant first tendering the deposit sum in cash. If the
construction is completed and the lands restored to their original condition
prior to the commencement of construction, within 60 days from the issuance of
the permit, weather permitting, then the Village shall return the deposit to
the applicant. The Village shall determine whether or not the applicant has
fully restored the lands to an appropriate pre-construction condition. If the
restoration is not completed within 60 days from the issuance of the permit,
weather permitting, or if the lands are not restored to the satisfaction of the
Village, then the Village shall retain the deposit sum to apply toward the cost
of restoration of the lands to their original condition. The Village may
reimburse itself, or an independent contractor, for the time and materials to
restore the lands. Any portion of the deposit sum not necessary to restore the
lands to their original condition, shall be returned to the applicant.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â The Village designates the Street Superintendent to be the individual
responsible for determining the propriety of the restoration of the lands
referenced herein.
(Ord. 01-3-6. Passed 3-13-01.)
1020.99Â Â Â PENALTY.
Â Â Â Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues.

Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â The minimum length drainage pipe for a driveway shall be 40 feet.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â The driveway entrance and driveway material to be used shall be of the

Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â From outside edge of the road within road right-of-way to property

Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Backfill without oversized #1 stone to bring close to grade with

Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â "Street trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes and other woody vegetation
of land lying within the right of way of all streets, avenues or ways within
the Village.

1024.03Â Â Â DANGEROUS TREES.
Â Â Â Dangerous trees are any trees which are either dead, diseased, insect
infested or otherwise in a blighted condition. Such trees shall be considered a
hazard to life and property and shall be removed by the owner of the property
within thirty days after written notice from the Tree Board. If the owner fails
to comply with such an order within the specified period, the Village shall
have cause and authority to enter the premises and remove such trees. In the
event that the Village removes trees due to the property owner's failure to
comply, the cost of removal shall be paid by the Village. (See Section
660.16 for provisions relating to pruning and corner clearance.)
(Ord. 86-5-2. Passed 6-10-86.)
1024.04Â Â Â STREET TREE PLANS REQUIRED.
Â Â Â Any new street developed by a private developer and dedicated to the Village
shall have a street tree plan approved by the Tree Board. As an alternative,
the developer may permit the Tree Board to develop the street plans with the
cost of all trees to be paid by the developer.
(Ord. 86-5-2. Passed 6-10-86.)
1024.05Â Â Â DAMAGE OR INJURY TO TREES.
Â Â Â Unless specifically authorized by the Tree Board, no person shall
intentionally damage any street or park tree, attach any rope, wire, rails,
advertising posters or other contrivance to any trees, allow any gaseous liquid
or solid substance which is harmful to trees to come into contact with them, or
set fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or heat therefrom will
injure any portion of any tree. (See Section
642.04 for provisions relating to damaging of trees.)
(Ord. 86-5-2. Passed 6-10-86.)
1024.06Â Â Â PROXIMITY OF TREES TO STREET CORNERS AND HYDRANTS.
Â Â Â No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five feet of any street
corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No
street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet of any fire hydrant.
(Ord. 86-5-2. Passed 6-10-86.)
1024.07Â Â Â PROTECTION OF TREES NEAR EXCAVATIONS OR CONSTRUCTION.
Â Â Â All trees on any street or other publicly owned property near any excavation
or the construction of any building, structure or street work shall be guarded
with a barrier sufficient to protect such trees from damage. No person shall
excavate ditches, tunnels or trenches, or lay any drive, within a radius of ten
feet from any public tree without first obtaining permission from the Tree
Board.
(Ord. 86-5-2. Passed 6-10-86.)
1024.08Â Â Â OBSTRUCTION OF OFFICERS OR EMPLOYEES.
Â Â Â No person shall hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the Tree Board, or
any of its agents, while engaged in carrying out the execution or enforcement
of this chapter, provided that nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt
to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of
competent jurisdiction for the protection of property rights by the owner of
any property within the Municipality.
(Ord. 86-5-2. Passed 6-10-86.)
1024.99Â Â Â PENALTY.
Â Â Â Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues.

1040.01Â Â Â LIABILITY OF PROPERTY OWNERS FOR CHARGES.

1040.02Â Â Â WATER AND SEWER TAPâIN DEPOSIT FEE FOR LAND RESTORATION.
Â Â Â In the case of a water, sanity sewer or storm sewer line tap, there is
hereby established a deposit in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to
secure restoration of the lands disturbed by the construction of the tap. The
deposit shall be paid to the Village at the time the tap is applied for and the
tap fee is paid. If construction of the tap is completed and the lands restored
within thirty days of the start of construction, then the Village shall return
the deposit. However, if restoration is not completed within thirty days of the
start of construction, then the Village may retain the deposit and apply it to
the cost of restoration by the Village. Any deposit not used by the Village for
restoration shall be returned. The Water and Sewer Superintendent shall be the
inspector of the restoration and the sole determiner of the adequacy of such
restoration. (Ord. 94â11â1. Passed 11â15â94.)

1040.04 WATER AND SEWER UTILITY BILLING PAYMENT PROCEDURE.
Â Â Â New rental utility customers will be required to provide an initial deposit
to be paid in cash as follows:
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â W/S Deposit Village Properties: $286.84 ($123.60 for water; $163.24
for sewer).
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â W/S Deposit Non-Village Properties: $401.56 ($173.04 for water;
$228.52 for sewer).
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Water sewer payment is due within thirty days from the date of the
bill.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Deposits shall increase by ten percent (10%) with all scheduled water
and sewer rate increase for fiscal years 2022 and 2023 hereinafter.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â All water/sewer payments may be made by cash, check, money order,
Mastercard or Discover credit/debit any business Monday through Friday from 8:
00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. The payment may be placed in the Village drop box located
at the Village Hall, mailed to the Village Hall or paid online through the
Village website.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â In cases where check(s) are returned for non-sufficient funds, the
billed party will make payment in cash within seventy-two hours of
notification. Any charge by the issuing bank for non-sufficient funds will be
the responsibility of the billed party. Failure to pay the bill and the bank
charge where applicable, within the seventy-two hour time limit, will result in
immediate disconnect of utility services. As a consequence, for a non-
sufficient fund return, the billed party will be required to make the next two
billing cycle payments in cash. If the same billed party should ever have
another check returned for non-sufficient funds, that party will be placed on
cash only payment basis for an indefinite period.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â After the thirtieth day from the billing date, the customer will be
charged a ten percent (10%) late fee as indicated on the bill to include the
service disconnect date (if payment has not been received by that time) and
reconnection fee (if service has been disconnected).
Â Â Â (h)Â Â Â To have service reconnected, the customer must pay in cash or credit/
debit card the outstanding balance owed, a ten percent (10%) late fee based on
the outstanding balance, the non-sufficient funds bank penalty where applicable
and a reconnection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Payments received after 2:00
p.m. will result in reconnection within one business day. Unpaid balances will
be assessed on the property of the registered owner as documented on the
Ashtabula County Auditor's website. Such assessments will be removed once
payment in full has been remitted. Property owners will be responsible for
unpaid utility service bills incurred by any tenant, past or present.
Â Â Â (i)Â Â Â With good reason as determined by the Village Manager, a bill may be
adjusted to a normal average usage figure for an unusual spike in usage and
will be granted only one time. However, filling of a swimming pool or excessive
outdoor watering or for any other impermissible use of services known to the
customer will not be considered for a billing adjustment. An adjustment may
only be applied toward a Village meter (not a private meter). Adjustments will
only be granted once within a five year period.
(Ord. 12-07-01. Passed 8-21-12; Ord. 14-11-01. Passed 12-19-14; Ord. 21-08- 01.
Passed 9-21-21; Ord. 22-09-02. Passed - - .)

1042.04Â Â Â BACKFLOW PREVENTION.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â If, in the judgment of the Board of Public Affairs, an approved
backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water
system, the Board of Public Affairs will give notice to the water consumer to
install such an approved device immediately. The water consumer shall, at his
or her own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a
manner approved by the Board of Public Affairs and shall have inspections and
tests made of such approved devices as required by the Board of Public Affairs.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of Orwell may enter the supply or distributing system of said
municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the
method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by Orwell
and the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â It shall be the duty of the Board of Public Affairs to cause surveys
and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the
public water supply where actual or potential hazards to the public water
supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of
public record and shall be repeated as often as the Board of Public Affairs
shall deem necessary.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â The Board of Public Affairs or its duly authorized representative
shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a
connection to the public water supply or distribution system of Orwell for the
purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof. On demand the
owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the
Board of Public Affairs any information which he or she may request regarding
the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such
information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the Board of Public
Affairs, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided
in this section.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â The Board of Public Affairs is hereby authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
section is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as
they may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public
water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be
restored until such conditions shall have been eliminated or corrected in
compliance with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 04-02-02. Passed 2-10-04.)

1044.01Â Â Â DEFINITIONS.
Â Â Â As used in this chapter:
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â "B.O.D." (biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen
utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard
laboratory procedure in five days at twenty degrees Centigrade, expressed in
parts per million by weight.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a
drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other
drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the lateral,
beginning three feet outside the inner face of the building wall.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â "Garbage" means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of products.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â "Industrial wastes" means the liquid wastes from industrial processes,
as distinct from sanitary sewage.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â "Lateral" means the extension from the building drain to the public
sewer or other place of disposal.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch,
lake or other body of surface or ground water.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â "Person" means any individual, firm, company, association, society,
corporation or group.
Â Â Â (h)Â Â Â "pH" means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen
ions in grams per liter of solution.
Â Â Â (i)Â Â Â "Private sewer" means a sewer which is not publicly owned and to which
all adjoining property owners do not have equal rights.
Â Â Â (j)Â Â Â "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation,
cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all
particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing
in public sewers, with no particle greater than three-eighths of an inch in any
dimension.
Â Â Â (k)Â Â Â "Public sewer" means a publicly owned sewer to which all adjoining
property owners have equal rights.
Â Â Â (l)Â Â Â "Sanitary sewer" means a pipe or conduit for carrying sanitary sewage.
Â Â Â (m)Â Â Â "Sewage" means a combination or any one of the water-carried wastes
from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial
establishments.
Â Â Â (n)Â Â Â "Sewage treatment plant" means any arrangement of devices and
structures used for treating sewage.
Â Â Â (o)Â Â Â "Sewage works" means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating
and disposing of sanitary sewage and industrial waste.
Â Â Â (p)Â Â Â "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
Â Â Â (q)Â Â Â "Storm sewer" or "storm drain" means a sewer which carries storm and
surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial
wastes.
Â Â Â (r)Â Â Â "Superintendent" means the Superintendent of the Division of Water and
Sewage of the Village, or his or her authorized deputy, agent or
representative.
Â Â Â (s)Â Â Â "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface or
are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by
laboratory filtering.
Â Â Â (t)Â Â Â "Village" means the Village of Orwell, Ohio.
Â Â Â (u)Â Â Â "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either
continuously or intermittently (Ord. 252. Passed 5-20-69.)
1044.02Â Â Â CONNECTION TO PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall discharge, to any natural outlet within the Village,
or in any area under the jurisdiction of the Village, any sanitary sewage,
industrial wastes or other polluted water, except where suitable treatment has
been provided in accordance with this chapter.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â No privy vault, cesspool, septic tank or other receptacle for sewage
shall be established, constructed, repaired, maintained or allowed to remain in
service or any lot or land in the Village if said lot or land abuts upon a
street, alley, avenue or public grounds which are provided with both the
sanitary sewer and Village water lines, or on any private grounds containing
such sewer or water lines or provided with the same. Any such receptacle or
other device or equipment for the treatment or disposal of sewage shall be
thoroughly cleaned and disinfected and filled to the ground surface with earth,
ashes or other suitable filling material.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â The owner of any house, building or other property used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the
Village and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now
located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the Village,
is hereby required, at his or her own expense, to install suitable toilet
facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper
public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter within 180 days
after the date of official notice to do so. Official notice shall be deemed to
mean notice to connect sent to the property owner by registered letter, or, in
the case of the completion of the original sanitary sewage treatment plant and
sanitary sewer lines of the Village, official notice to connect shall be by
notice published for two consecutive weeks in a local weekly newspaper of
general circulation and the effective date of such published notice shall be
the date of the second publication.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â The Board of Trustees of Public Affairs may grant limited time
extensions for connecting with the proper public sewer, upon written
application for such time extension by the property owner, where the situation
warrants such an extension in the sole judgement of the Board. (Ord. 252.
Passed 5-20-69.)
1044.03Â Â Â SEWER PERMIT REQUIRED; INSTALLATION OF LATERALS; CONSTRUCTION
SPECIFICATIONS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, or
use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first
obtaining a written permit from the Superintendent.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â A sewer permit shall be required of all property owners for
residential and commercial service, and for service to establishments producing
industrial wastes. In any case, the owner or his or her agent shall make
application on a form furnished by the Village. The permit application shall be
supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered
pertinent in the judgement of the Superintendent. A permit and inspection fee
as determined from time to time by Council for each residential, commercial or
any industrial builder shall be paid to the Village Clerk at the time the
application is filed.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â At the Superintendent's request, the sewer, drain, lateral or
connection thereto shall be subject to a test at the owner's expense in the
presence of the Superintendent. A water test shall be made as follows: The
lateral, or a portion thereof, shall be tested by inserting a test plug at the
point of connection of the lateral with the public sewer, and the lateral shall
be filled so as to produce a ten-foot head of water. The water shall be kept in
the lateral, or in that portion under test, for at least fifteen minutes before
the inspection starts. The lateral shall then be watertight at all points. An
air test may be applied in lieu of a water test upon acquiring prior approval
from the Superintendent. The final results of the air test shall be such as to
produce a tight system equivalent to that produced under the water test.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of
the lateral shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the Village
from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the
installation of the lateral.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â A separate and independent lateral shall be provided for every
building, except that, where one building stands at the rear of another on an
interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the
rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, then the
lateral from the front building may be extended to the rear building and each
building shall be considered a separate sewer connection and subject to the
charges provided for in subsection (b) hereof, and separately charged for water
and sewer.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â Old laterals may be used in connection with new buildings only when
they are found, on examination and test by the Superintendent, to meet all
requirements of this chapter.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â All sanitary sewers and laterals within the Village shall be in
accordance with one of the following: extra strength cast iron soil pipe with
lead-caulked joints (latest ASTM Specification); Standard Strength Clay Pipe
(ASTM C-13) and Extra Strength Clay Pipe (ASTM C-200); Asbestos-cement
nonpressure sewer pipe, classes 1500 and 2400 (ASTM C-4281); or plastic sewer
pipe, 1,000 pound and 1,600 pound crushing strength (Commercial Standards, U.S.
Department of Commerce, #C.S. 228-61.)
Â Â Â (h)Â Â Â The size and slope of the lateral shall be subject to the approval of
the Superintendent, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four
inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall be not less than one-eighth of
an inch per foot. The lowest inlet to said sanitary sewer later, however, must
not be less than eighteen inches above the top of the public sewer to which the
lateral is connected.
Â Â Â (i)Â Â Â Whenever possible, the lateral shall be brought to the building at an
elevation below the basement floor. No lateral shall be laid parallel to or
within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The
depth shall be not less than forty-two inches to the top of the sewer pipe. The
lateral shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as
possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and
fittings, and there shall be accessible clean outs properly placed at any
change of direction of more than forty-five degrees.
Â Â Â (j)Â Â Â In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit
gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall
be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer.
Â Â Â (k)Â Â Â All excavations required for the installation of a lateral shall be
open trench work unless otherwise approved by the Superintendent. Pipe laying
and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specifications, except
that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. The inside
of every sewer after it is laid must be left smooth and clean throughout its
entire length, and be true to line and grade.
Â Â Â (l)Â Â Â Joints on cast iron pipe shall be either caulked joints with oakum or
hemp and lead or compression joints with pre-formed molded ring or collar.
Joints on clay pipe shall be compression or pressure type made of plasticized
polyvinylcholride resin with suitable inert fillers in accordance with ASTM
Specification C-425-66T. Joints on asbestos-cement pipe shall be asbestos-
cement pipe coupling sealed with suitable rubber sealing rings or gaskets in
accordance with ASTM Specification D-1869. Plastic pipe joints shall be made
with "O" ring method conforming to ASTM Specification C-443 or with a
chemically welded method using proper cleaning solvents, primer, pipe cement
and couplings.
Â Â Â When assembled and backfilled, the joint shall exert sufficient pressure on
the entire circumference of the joint surface so as to prevent the entrance of
roots and the infiltration of subsurface water. All joints between piping of
different material shall be made with suitable jointing material and methods as
approved by the Superintendent.
Â Â Â (m)Â Â Â The connection of a lateral into the public sewer shall be made at the
"Y" branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. If the public
sewer is eight inches in diameter or less, and no properly located "Y" branch
is available, the owner shall, at his or her own expense, install a "Y" branch
in the public sewer at the location approved by the Superintendent. Where the
public sewer is greater than eight inches in diameter, and no properly located
"Y" branch is available, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer with a
compatible saddle installed at the owner's expense to receive the lateral, with
entry in the downstream direction at an angle. The invert of the lateral at the
point of connection shall be at an elevation at least one-half the pipe
diameter of the public sewer above the invert of said sewer. A smooth, neat
joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by
encasement in concrete.
Â Â Â (n)Â Â Â The applicant for the lateral sewer permit shall notify the
Superintendent when the lateral is ready for inspection and connection to the
public sewer. The connection shall be made by the applicant under the
supervision of the Superintendent or his or her representative.
Â Â Â (o)Â Â Â All excavations for lateral installation shall be adequately guarded
with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets,
sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the
work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the Village. (Ord. 252.
Passed 5-20-69.)
1044.04Â Â Â PROHIBITED DISCHARGES; GREASE, OIL AND SAND INTERCEPTORS; PRELIMINARY
OR PRIVATE TREATMENT FACILITIES; CONTROL MANHOLE.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water,
surface water, ground water, roof drainage, foundation drainage, subsoil
drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process water to any sanitary
sewer. Where existing roof drainage is not properly connected, the same shall
be replaced or repaired in accordance with this chapter.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to
such sewers as are specifically designated storm sewers, or to a natural outlet
approved by the Superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process
waters may be discharged, upon the approval of the Superintendent, to a storm
sewer or natural outlet.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall discharge or cause to
be discharged any of the following described waters or waste to any public
sewer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 180 degrees
Fahrenheit.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 parts per
million, by weight, of fat, oil, or grease.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Any gasoline, benzine, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid or gas.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Any garbage that has not been properly shredded.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastic, wood, paunch manure or any other solid or viscous
substances capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other
interference with the proper operation of the sewage works.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0
or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (7)Â Â Â Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous substances in
sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process,
constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the receiving
waters of the sewage treatment plant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (8)Â Â Â Any waters or wastes containing suspended or settlable solids of
such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to
handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (9)Â Â Â Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a
public nuisance or hazard to life or of preventing entry into sewers for
maintenance and repair.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, of the
opinion of the Superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of
liquid wastes containing grease or excessive amounts of any flammable wastes,
sand and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be
required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall
be of a type and capacity approved by the Superintendent, and shall be so
located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. All
such interceptors shall be in compliance with the Ohio Plumbing Code.
Â Â Â Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials
capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall
be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable
covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight.
Â Â Â (e)Â Â Â  Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be
maintained by the owner, at his or her expense, in continuously efficient
operation at all times.
Â Â Â The Superintendent shall be permitted to enter upon properties containing
such grease, oil and sand interceptors at any time for the purposes of
inspection, observation, sampling or testing.
Â Â Â (f)Â Â Â The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having a
five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 250 parts per million by
weight, containing more than 300 parts per million by weight of suspended
solids, containing any quantity of substances having characteristics described
in subsection (d) hereof, or having an average daily flow greater than two
percent of the average daily sewage flow of the Village, shall be subject to
the review and approval of Council. Where necessary in the opinion of Council,
the owner shall provide, at his or her own expense, such preliminary treatment
as may be necessary to reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 250 parts per
million and the suspended solids to 300 parts per million by weight, reduce
objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits
provided for in subsection (d) hereof, or control the quantities and rates of
discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications and any other
pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment or private
treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of Council, and
Council shall in turn submit such plans to the Ohio Department of Health as
required by law, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced
until said approvals are obtained in writing.
Â Â Â (g)Â Â Â Where preliminary treatment facilities or private treatment facilities
are provided for any waters or wastes, such facilities shall be maintained
continuously in satisfactory and effective operation, by the owner at his or
her own expense. The right to enter upon and inspect such preliminary treatment
facilities is reserved to the Village. The owner of such preliminary treatment
facilities shall be liable for any damage to the Village sanitary sewage
system. The owner shall maintain proper operating records and shall submit to
the Superintendent a monthly summary report of the character of the influent
and effluent, in such form as may be prescribed by the Village, in order to
show satisfactory performance of the treatment facilities.
Â Â Â (h)Â Â Â When required by the Superintendent, the owner of any property served
by a lateral carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control
manhole in the lateral to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of
the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely
located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the
Superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his or her own
expense, and shall be maintained by him or her so as to be safe and accessible
at all times.
Â Â Â (i)Â Â Â All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of water
and wastes to which reference is made in subsections (c) and (f) hereof shall
be determined in accordance with "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water
and Sewage" and shall be determined at the control manhole provided for in
subsection (h) hereof, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole.
In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole
shall be considered to be the nearest down-stream manhole in the public sewer
to the point at which the lateral is connected.
Â Â Â (j)Â Â Â No statement contained in this section shall be construed as
preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the Village and any
industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character
may be accepted by the Village for treatment, subject to payment therefor by
the industrial concern.
(Ord. 252. Passed 5-20-69.)
1044.05Â Â Â INSTALLATION OF ADDITIONAL WATER METERS IN COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Where a commercial establishment in the Village uses more than 20,000
gallons of water per quarter for four consecutive quarters for a certain
special purpose and none of the water used for such special purpose is directly
or indirectly drained into the sanitary sewer system, then the owner of such a
commercial establishment may apply to the Board of Trustees of Public Affairs
for permission to install on his or her premises a second water meter for the
measurement of the water used for the said special purpose. The readings of
this second water meter shall in no way be used to figure the sewer service
charge of such owner.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â The second water meter shall be installed and inspected entirely at
the expense of the owner and may be removed by the Board, also at the owner's
expense, if the owner uses less than an average of 20,000 gallons per quarter
for four consecutive quarters.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â Permission to install a second water meter for the purpose set out in
subsection (a) hereof or the order to remove the second water meter as set out
in subsection (b) hereof shall be issued by the Board according to this
chapter, as interpreted by the Board, in its sole judgment and discretion.
(Ord. 252. Passed 5- 20-69.)
1044.06Â Â Â TAMPERING WITH AND DAMAGING FACILITIES.
Â Â Â No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently damage,
destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or
equipment which is a part of the Municipal sewage works.
(Ord. 252. Passed 5-20-69.)
1044.07Â Â Â INSPECTIONS.
Â Â Â The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the Village
bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon
all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 252. Passed 5-20-69.)
1044.08Â Â Â NOTICE OF VIOLATION.
Â Â Â The Village shall serve written notice upon any person found to be in
violation of the provisions of this chapter, with the exception of Section
1044.06, stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time
limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the
period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations.
(Ord. 252. Passed 5-20-69.)
1044.09Â Â Â TERMINATION OF SERVICE FOR FAILURE TO CONNECT; WATER CONSUMPTION
METER REQUIRED; PAYMENT OF BILLS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â As the sewer service charge is based on water consumption and the
maintenance of the sewer system is dependent on funds obtained from the sewer
service charges, the Village may cut off the water supply to any property owner
who has not complied with the 180-day notice to connect with the public sewer
as set out in Section
1044.02(c), provided that such property owner has not applied for and received
an extension of time in which to connect to the public sewer as set out in
Section
1044.02(d).
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Any property owner served by a public sewer and not served by public
water must, at the property owner's sole expense, have installed a water
consumption meter within ten days of being notified to do so by the
Superintendent.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â The Village will not accept payment of any water bill without payment
also of the sewer bill, and if any bill remains unpaid for thirty days, the
Village may cut off the water supply to such sewer owner until the sewer bill
is paid.
(Ord. 421. Passed 7-13-82.)
1044.10Â Â Â STATE STANDARDS ADOPTED.
Â Â Â The code of standards of the State of Ohio for the installation of sewer
lines (the "Ten- States Standards") is hereby adopted as the code for the
installation of sewer lines for the Village. Copies of the Standards may be
obtained, at cost, from the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 377. Passed 11-27-79.)

1044.99Â Â Â PENALTY; LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned for not more than six months, or both.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â In addition to the penalty provided in subsection (a) hereof, any
person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to
the Village for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by reason of such
violation.
(Ord. 252. Passed 5-20-69.)

CHAPTER 1060
Garbage, Rubbish and Recycling
EDITOR'S NOTE: The Village approves and ratifies the Ashtabula County Solid
Waste Management Plan from time to time by ordinance. The Village also
approves, from time to time by ordinance, the fees adopted by the Solid Waste
Management Policy Committee of the Ashtabula, Geauga and Trumbull Joint Solid
Waste Management District to be charged for the disposal of solid wastes.
Â Â Â Copies of the latest relevant legislation may be obtained, at cost, at the
Village Hall.

1060.99Â Â Â Penalty.

1060.01Â Â Â RECYCLING.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Definitions. As used in this section:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership or association which owns, operates or leases a residential
or commercial use within the Village, as defined in the Zoning Code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â "Recyclable material" means the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Newspaper. Used or discarded newsprint, but excluding glossy
inserts, magazines, books, catalogs, telephone books and any other paper.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Cardboard. Any box or packaging made from paperboard, cardboard,
corrugated paper material, cereal boxes, cracker boxes or brown paper bags, but
excluding cardboard with wax coating, shiny surface or foil coating.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Glass. Any bottle or jar that is clear, green or brown, but
excluding window glass, drinking glasses, light bulbs, frosted glass and any
other glass.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Aluminum cans. Any soda pop cans and beer cans, excluding
aluminum foil, cooking trays and any other aluminum.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Tin cans. Any food cans, pet food cans and coffee cans, but
excluding clothes hangers, aerosol spray cans, cans used for paints or
chemicals, motor oil cans, and any other metal products.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Plastic. Any milk jugs, water jugs, one or two-liter soda
bottles, liquor bottles, fabric softener bottles, bleach bottles, laundry
detergent bottles, but excluding shampoo bottles, margarine tubs, styrofoam,
and any other plastic.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â "Recycle" means the separation of recyclable materials from other
household refuse for the purpose of recovery and reuse of the materials.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â "Refuse" means garbage and rubbish, as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â "Garbage" means all putrescible vegetable and animal food wastes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â "Refuse" means household or commercial waste other than garbage.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Disposal of Refuse and Recyclables. Effective January 1, 1996, all
persons within the Village shall dispose of residential refuse and recyclable
materials in accordance with the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â A person shall contract with a refuse and recyclable materials
hauler approved by the Village (a "hauler") to dispose of refuse and recycle
recyclable material.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â A person shall dispose of refuse weekly:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â By putting it either in:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Four standard size refuse cans or five thirty-gallon plastic
refuse bags; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â One molded plastic refuse cart of a size to match the person's
refuse generation; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â By placing the cans, bags or cart at the tree lawn or the
curbside for pick-up by a hauler.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â A person shall recycle weekly:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â By putting all recyclable materials into an eighteen-gallon
orange recycling bin; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â By placing the bin at the tree lawn or the curbside for pick-up
when refuse is collected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â In the case of a person owning, operating or leasing a commercial
use, a person may dispose of refuse and recycle weekly by contracting with a
hauler to both dispose of refuse and recycle recyclable material.
(Ord. 95-1-2. Passed 6-13-95.)
1060.01Â Â Â PENALTY.
Â Â Â Whoever violates any of the provisions of the chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 95-1-2. Passed 6-13-95.)
CHAPTER 1062
Orwell Area Joint Recreation District

Â Â Â Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01

1062.01Â Â Â AGREEMENT FOR JOINT OPERATION WITH ORWELL TOWNSHIP.
Â Â Â Council of the Village of Orwell and the Trustees of Orwell Township hereby
agree to join in the operation and maintenance of joint recreation facilities
for the residents of said political subdivisions.
(Res. 95-12-2R. Passed 12-13-95.)
1062.02Â Â Â ESTABLISHMENT; JURISDICTION.
Â Â Â The Orwell Area Joint Recreation District is hereby established to govern
the operation and maintenance of the parks, playgrounds, playfields,
recreational facilities and community centers owned by the District, which
District shall possess all the powers and be subject to all the
responsibilities of the respective local authorities under Ohio R.C. 755.12 to
755.181, inclusive, but the District shall not govern the operation and
maintenance of parks, playgrounds, playfields, recreational facilities, and
community centers owned by any municipal corporation or township within the
District.
(Res. 95-12-2R. Passed 12-13-95.)
1062.03Â Â Â BOARD OF TRUSTEES; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS.
Â Â Â The Orwell Area Joint Recreation District Board of Trustees shall consist of
five members. The Council of the Village of Orwell, by majority vote, shall
select two designees to serve on the Board, none of whom may be a member of the
Village Council. The Board of Orwell Township Trustees shall select, by
majority vote, two designees to serve on the Board, none of whom may be a
member of the Township Board of Trustees. Then, the Board of the Grand Valley
School District shall, by majority vote, select a fifth member, who shall be a
resident of the Grand Valley School District. One representative serving Orwell
Township, and one representative serving the Village of Orwell, shall serve for
a term of five years. One representative serving the Village of Orwell, and one
representative serving Orwell Township, shall serve for a term of three years.
The fifth representative shall serve for a term of two years. All appointments
made thereafter shall be for a term of five years. Vacancies on the Board
occurring otherwise than by expiration of a term shall be for the unexpired
term and shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointments.
Members of the Board shall serve without pay.
(Res. 95-12-2R. Passed 12-13-95.)
1062.04Â Â Â APPLICATION FOR MEMBERSHIP; WITHDRAWAL; DISSOLUTION.
Â Â Â Any municipal corporation or township located, in whole or in part, within
the boundaries of the Grand Valley School District, and which is not a member
of the Orwell Area Joint Recreation District at its inception, may join the
existing Orwell Area Joint Recreation District by the adoption of a resolution
requesting such membership by petition in accordance with Ohio R.C. 755.181,
and upon approval, by resolution of the members of said Board.
Â Â Â Any member may withdraw from the Orwell Area Joint Recreation District by
the adoption of a resolution ordering said withdrawal.
Â Â Â When the number of political subdivisions comprising the Orwell Area Joint
Recreation District is increased or decreased, a joint resolution shall be
passed by all members restructuring the Board composition.
Â Â Â In the event the District membership is reduced to one political
subdivision, the Orwell Area Joint Recreation District shall cease to exist.
(Res. 95-12-2R. Passed 12-13-95.)
1062.05Â Â Â AUTHORITY.
Â Â Â The Orwell Area Joint Recreation District shall operate under authority
granted by Ohio R.C. 755.12 to 755.181, inclusive, and any amendments or
additions thereto that may be hereafter enacted.
(Res. 95-12-2R. Passed 12-13-95.)

PART FOURTEEN â BUILDING AND HOUSING CODE
CHAPTER 1410
Numbering of Buildings
1410.01Â Â Â Numbering required.
1410.02Â Â Â Numbering sequence.
1410.03Â Â Â Assignment of numbers.
1410.04Â Â Â Placement; visibility; cost.
1410.99Â Â Â Penalty.
Â Â Â CROSS REFERENCES
Â Â Â Power to regulate building numbering - see Ohio R.C. 715.26
1410.01Â Â Â NUMBERING REQUIRED.
Â Â Â All buildings in the Village located upon any road or street and used as a
business or residence shall be numbered by the owners thereof in accordance
with the maps and plans on file in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 124. Passed 5-18-54.)
1410.02Â Â Â NUMBERING SEQUENCE.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Numbers shall start running from zero from the intersection of U.S.
Highway 322 and State Route 45, towards the limits of the Village, even numbers
being used only upon the right hand side, odd numbers being used only upon the
left side, facing away from said intersection. This applies to North Maple
Street, South Maple Street, East Main Street and West Main Street.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â All other streets within the Village shall be numbered from zero
beginning with the intersection of such a street with U.S. Route 322, State
Route 45, or the intersection of the projection of said street with U.S. 322 or
State Route 45, whichever is more nearly perpendicular to said street.
(Ord. 124. Passed 5-18-54.)
1410.03Â Â Â ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS.
Â Â Â Numbers shall be assigned by the Clerk-Treasurer based upon the following:
One digit shall be represented every twenty linear feet. Numbers shall commence
at the intersectional beginning of the street and run towards the end of the
street or the Village limits.
(Ord. 124. Passed 5-18-54.)
1410.04Â Â Â PLACEMENT; VISIBILITY; COST.
Â Â Â All numbers shall be placed upon the houses and buildings assigned in the
center of the top step riser, or upon the door or beside the door so that they
are clearly visible from the street front. The cost of the numbers and their
installation shall be borne by the owner of the house or building.
(Ord. 124. Passed 5-18-54.)
1410.99Â Â Â PENALTY.
Â Â Â Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or upon which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.

Chapter 872
1610.01Â Â Â 1998 EDITION ADOPTED.
Â Â Â Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 731.231, there is hereby adopted by the Village the
1998 edition of the Ohio Fire Code (OFC), as adopted by the Ohio Department of
Commerce, Division of State Fire Marshal, published in Division 1301:7 of the
Ohio Administrative Code (OAC).
1610.02Â Â Â PURPOSE.
Â Â Â The purpose of the Ohio Fire Code, as adopted in Section
1610.01, is to prescribe minimum standards and regulations governing conditions
hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion.
1610.03Â Â Â APPLICATION OF CODE.
Â Â Â The Ohio Fire Code, as adopted in Section
1610.01, applies to the use of all lands and properties within the Village and
such other lands or properties owned by the Village which are situated outside
the corporate limits thereof.
1610.04Â Â Â ENFORCEMENT; RESPONSIBILITIES OF MUNICIPAL FIRE SAFETY INSPECTOR.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall serve as a Municipal Fire Safety Inspector unless he
or she has received a certificate issued by the Ohio Superintendent of Public
Instruction under Ohio R.C. 3303.07 evidencing his or her satisfactory
completion of a fire safety inspection training program.
(ORC 3737.34)
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â The Municipal Fire Safety Inspector, upon examination or inspection,
shall issue citations when he or she finds conditions as specified in Ohio R.C.
3737.41 which are especially dangerous to the safety of persons, buildings,
premises or property, and shall make any necessary remedial orders in
connection therewith. Citation enforcement may be by use of the procedures
established by Ohio R.C. 3737.42 for hearing on the citation or Ohio R.C.
3737.44 for injunctive relief or a temporary restraining order and oral order
for vacation of the building or premises.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â The Municipal Fire Safety Inspector, upon reasonable belief and after
inspection or investigation, shall, with reasonable promptness, issue a
citation to the responsible person for a violation of the Ohio Fire Code or any
order issued by the Ohio Fire Marshal or any Municipal Fire Safety Inspector.
The citation shall fix a reasonable time for abatement of the violation. Each
citation issued under this subsection shall be prominently posted by the
responsible person, as prescribed by the Ohio Fire Code, at or near each place
a violation referred to in the citation occurs.
Â Â Â (d)Â Â Â Upon request of the Municipal Fire Safety Inspector, the Village
Solicitor shall institute and prosecute any necessary action or proceeding to
enforce this chapter or Ohio R.C. Chapter 3737.
1610.05Â Â Â COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall knowingly violate any provision of the Ohio Fire Code,
as adopted in Section
1610.01, or any order issued pursuant thereto.
(ORC 3737.51(A))
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â No person shall fail to comply with the fire prevention measures or
fire protection activities prescribed in the Ohio Fire Code or fail to comply
with the Municipal application and plan submission and processing requirements,
including payment of the fees designated therefor.
1610.06Â Â Â POSTING ARSON LAWS.
Â Â Â The owner, operator or lessee of any hotel, motel or transient residential
building shall post the provisions of Ohio R.C. 2909.02 and 2909.03 regarding
aggravated arson and arson, in a conspicuous place in each room occupied by
guests in such building. The owner, operator or lessee of any nontransient
residential building, institution, school or place of assembly shall post the
provisions of such sections in conspicuous places upon such premises. No person
shall fail to comply with this section.
(ORC 3737.61)
1610.07Â Â Â SETTING FIRES WHICH SPREAD.
Â Â Â No person shall set, kindle or cause to be set or kindled any fire which,
through his or her negligence, spreads beyond its immediate confines to any
structure, field or wood lot.
(ORC 3737.62)
1610.08Â Â Â RESPONSIBILITIES UPON DISCOVERY OF UNFRIENDLY FIRES.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â The owner, operator or lessee, an employee of any owner, operator or
lessee, an occupant, and any person in direct control of any building regulated
under the Ohio Basic Building Code, upon the discovery of an unfriendly fire or
upon receiving information that there is an unfriendly fire on the premises,
shall immediately and with all reasonable dispatch and diligence call or
otherwise notify the Morgan Township Volunteer Fire Department concerning the
fire and shall spread an alarm immediately to all occupants of the building.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â For the purposes of this section, "unfriendly fire" means a fire of a
destructive nature as distinguished from a controlled fire intended for a
beneficial purpose.
Â Â Â (c)Â Â Â No person shall fail to comply with this section.
(ORC 3737.63)
1610.09Â Â Â INSPECTIONS.
Â Â Â No person who is not a certified Fire Safety Inspector shall act as such or
hold himself or herself out to be such unless, prior to commencing any
inspection function, he or she discloses the purpose for which he or she is
making such inspection and the fact that he or she is not employed by any state
or local fire service or agency and that he or she is not acting in an official
capacity for any governmental subdivision or agency.
(ORC 3737.64)
1610.10Â Â Â SALE AND USE OF FIRE EQUIPMENT; STANDARDS; SERVICE AND REPAIR OF
EQUIPMENT.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â No person shall sell, offer for sale, or use any fire protection or
fire-fighting equipment that does not meet the minimum standards established by
the Ohio Fire Marshal in the Ohio Fire Code.
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Except for public and private mobile fire trucks, no person shall
service, test, repair or install for profit any fire protection or fire-
fighting equipment without a certificate or a provisional certificate issued by
the Ohio Fire Marshal.
(ORC 3737.65)
1610.11Â Â Â FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.
Â Â Â At least one copy of the Ohio Fire Code, as adopted in Section
1610.01, is on file with the Clerk-Treasurer for inspection by the public. At
lease one copy of such Code is also on file in the County Law Library. In
addition, the Clerk-Treasurer shall keep copies of such Code available for
distribution to the public, at cost.
1610.12Â Â Â CONFLICTS OF LAWS.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â The Ohio Basic Building Code shall supersede and govern any order,
standard, rule or regulation of the Ohio Fire Code or the Division of State
Fire Marshal, Department of Commerce, in all cases where any such order,
standard, rule or regulation is in conflict with the Ohio Basic Building Code,
except that rules adopted and orders issued by the Fire Marshal pursuant to
Ohio R.C. Chapter 3743 prevail in the event of a conflict.
(OAC 4101:2-1-04(B); ORC 3781.11(B))
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â In all other cases of conflict between the Ohio Fire Code and any
other Village ordinance or technical code adopted thereby, the stricter
standard shall control.
1610.13Â Â Â PERMIT FEES.
Â Â Â The fee for all permits issued by the Chief of the Morgan Township Volunteer
Fire Department or the Municipal Fire Safety Inspector pursuant to Section
1301:7-1-04 (FM-103.0) of the Ohio Fire Code shall be seventy-five dollars
($75.00) unless specifically indicated otherwise in the Ohio Fire Code.
1610.99Â Â Â PENALTY.
Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â Criminal Penalties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Whoever violates Section
1610.05(a) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined
not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six
months, or both. (ORC 3737.99(B))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Whoever violates Section
1610.05(b) or 1610.06 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). (ORC 3737.99(C))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Whoever violates Section
1610.07 or 1610.09 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be
fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more
than thirty days, or both.
(ORC 3737.99(D))
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Whoever violates Section
1610.08 or 1610.10 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be
fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than
sixty days, or both.
(ORC 3737.99(E))
Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â Civil Penalties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Any person who has received a citation for a serious violation of
the Ohio Fire Code or any order issued pursuant to it shall be assessed a civil
penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each such violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Any person who has received a citation for a violation of the Ohio
Fire Code or any order issued pursuant to it, and such violation is
specifically determined not to be of a serious nature, may be assessed a civil
penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each such violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Any person who fails to correct a violation for which a citation
has been issued, within the period permitted for its correction, may be
assessed a civil penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for
each day during which such failure or violation continues.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (4)Â Â Â Any person who violates any of the posting requirements prescribed
by Section
1610.04(c) shall be assessed a civil penalty of not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000) for each violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (5)Â Â Â Due consideration to the appropriateness of the penalty with
respect to the gravity of the violation, the good faith of the person being
charged and the history of previous violations shall be given whenever a
penalty is assessed under this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â (6)Â Â Â For purposes of this section, a serious violation shall be
considered to exist if there is a substantial probability that an occurrence
causing death or serious physical harm to persons could result from a condition
which exists, or from one or more practices, means, methods, operations or
processes which have been adopted or are in use, unless the person did not and
